text:
Vies effr√©n√©es





Donc, les gens peuvent avoir des rythmes diff√©rents pour leurs horloges : votre vitesse en RG est votre vitesse dans l‚Äôespace plus votre vitesse dans le temps. Cette vitesse est la rapidit√© avec laquelle vous ressentez le temps. Toutes les th√©ories doivent supposer quelque chose qu‚Äôelles ne peuvent pas prouver : en RG, la vitesse de la lumi√®re est suppos√©e √™tre toujours la m√™me o√π que la mesure soit effectu√©e et la vitesse totale espace+temps de tout objet est √©gale √† la vitesse de la lumi√®re.
Les math√©matiques de la RG sugg√®rent que nous vivons sur une feuille de papier (mais en r√©alit√© 4 dimensions, pas 2) qui peut √™tre pli√©e lorsqu‚Äôil y a un objet massif dessus. Lorsque vous tombez de l‚Äôespace vers une plan√®te, c‚Äôest comme glisser le long d‚Äôun toboggan qui m√®ne √† la plan√®te. En regardant la courbe du toboggan, vous pouvez voir que la notion d‚Äôespace et de temps d√©pend de l‚Äôendroit o√π vous √™tes (mais aussi de quand). Une ligne courbe est en effet plus longue qu‚Äôune ligne droite : cela explique pourquoi diff√©rentes personnes vivent des temps de voyage diff√©rents dans l‚Äôespace et le temps. Vous ou n‚Äôimporte quoi (plan√®tes, trous noirs, gaz, etc., mais aussi lumi√®re) subissez la courbure de l‚Äôespace-temps et en retour, la courbez √©galement. Toujours l√† ? Bien.

√âtoiles mais pas c√©l√©brit√©s





La Terre est l‚Äôune des 8 plan√®tes en orbite autour d‚Äôune √©toile ‚Äì notre soleil. Chacune d‚Äôelles a des mouvements suppl√©mentaires : elles tournent autour d‚Äôun axe Nord-Sud et cet axe oscille l√©g√®rement. Les orbites sont presque toutes circulaires, dans la m√™me direction (sauf V√©nus et Uranus), et toutes dans le m√™me plan. Comme toutes les plan√®tes faisaient partie de la m√™me nu√©e de mati√®re en orbite autour du soleil, leurs nombreux traits communs ne sont pas surprenants !
La gravit√© n‚Äôest pas sp√©cifique √† notre syst√®me. Nos plan√®tes et √©toiles n‚Äôont rien de sp√©cial non plus. Le m√™me agencement pourrait exister pour les ~100 milliards d‚Äô√©toiles de notre galaxie, la Voie lact√©e. title: Mon doctorat en 12 esquisses.
text:
Mo√Øse dans une mer cosmique ?





Continuons de d√©-zoomer, nous n‚Äôavons pas encore atteint l‚Äô√©chelle de la cosmologie, mais nous sommes sur le point d‚Äôy arriver. La Voie lact√©e appartient √† un super-amas de galaxies appel√© ‚ÄòVirgo‚Äô, un million de fois plus grand. Certains mouvements de ces galaxies ont √©t√© mesur√©s depuis la Terre. En 1929, Edwin Hubble a mesur√© que certaines galaxies s‚Äô√©loignent de nous et du super-amas, plus elles sont loin, plus elles s‚Äô√©loignent rapidement. Il semble que les distances augmentent partout : c‚Äôest une preuve que l‚Äôunivers est en expansion.
Cependant, √† une certaine distance de nous, les galaxies restent avec nous et le cluster et pourraient m√™me se rapprocher. Nous verrons que cela provient de la comp√©tition entre deux forces : la gravit√© et l‚Äôexpansion, toutes deux d√©crites par la RG. Si l‚Äôexpansion continue, il est difficile de pr√©dire exactement combien de galaxies resteront dans Virgo ; il sera probablement s√©par√© en une centaine de sous-amas de galaxies, qui pourraient se regrouper davantage jusqu‚Äô√† fusionner en super galaxies.

title: Mon doctorat en 12 esquisses.
text:
Toile Cosmique





L‚Äô√©chelle la plus grande que nous pouvons sonder par observations est appel√©e la ‚Äòtoile cosmique‚Äô, 10 millions de super-amas comme Virgo. Leur distribution dans l‚Äôespace a un sch√©ma de toile clair : les super-amas se sont regroup√©s avec d‚Äôautres gr√¢ce √† la gravit√©, mais aussi des bulles vides se sont form√©es gr√¢ce √† l‚Äôexpansion de l‚Äôunivers.
Comment est-ce possible ? On a l‚Äôimpression qu‚Äôil y a quelque chose qui pousse les choses au loin que nous ne pouvons pas voir. Mais nous pouvons le voir et c‚Äôest partout : la mati√®re, la lumi√®re, tout ce qui a de l‚Äô√©nergie dilate l‚Äôespace et c‚Äôest quelque chose que nous apprenons en √©crivant l‚Äô√©quation de la RG pour l‚Äôunivers. Cependant, il y a aussi quelque chose qui acc√©l√®re cette expansion, ce qui explique pourquoi nous pensons que l‚Äôexpansion ne s‚Äôarr√™tera pas et ne s‚Äôinversera pas. Aucun des types habituels de mati√®re, de lumi√®re ou de forces ne permet cela : pouvez-vous imaginer quelque chose avec une pression n√©gative ? Il y a autre chose l√†-bas, mais personne ne sait ce que c‚Äôest et c‚Äôest pourquoi on l‚Äôappelle maintenant l‚Äô√©nergie noire. title: Mon doctorat en 12 esquisses.

Une histoire √† rebours du temps





L‚Äôune des fa√ßons les plus simples de repr√©senter l‚Äôexpansion est d‚Äôutiliser un ballon qui se gonfle (inexact). Cela montre ce que vous voyez depuis le centre du ballon, vous (galaxie) et vos amis environnants (galaxies). Certains de vos amis sont assez loin pour se tenir √† la surface du ballon : c‚Äôest l‚Äôexpansion. Donc, si l‚Äôunivers est actuellement un gros ballon gonfl√© ; que se passe-t-il en remontant dans le temps ? Arrivez-vous √† √©treindre tous vos amis ? Qu‚Äôest-ce qu‚Äôun point qui s‚Äôembrasse lui-m√™me ? Eh bien, c‚Äôest essentiellement l‚Äôorigine des temps et c‚Äôest compliqu√©. Quelle est la bonne fa√ßon de remonter dans le temps ? C‚Äôest le travail des chercheurs de le d√©couvrir et tout d√©pend du contenu de l‚Äôunivers dans le temps. Pour l‚Äôinstant, nous avons d√©couvert que tous les types de mati√®re, lumi√®re et force habituels disparaissent dans un plasma chaud avant d‚Äôatteindre le ballon ponctuel. L‚Äô√©chec du vieux Big-Bang contre l‚Äôexpansion en 18 trous





Nous mesurons les distances en mesurant le trajet de la lumi√®re, la vitesse la plus rapide permise. Mais √† quelle vitesse se produit l‚Äôexpansion ? Cela signifie toujours que la lumi√®re envoy√©e de nous ou d‚Äôun voisin lointain pourrait devoir rivaliser avec une distance croissante, et parfois l‚Äôexpansion l‚Äôemporte. Nous parvenons toujours √† recevoir des signaux micro-ondes du plasma du Big-Bang, voyageant encore aujourd‚Äôhui, venant de toutes les directions. text:
L‚Äôinflation en pratique





Il n‚Äôy a pas vraiment de fa√ßon partag√©e d‚Äôimaginer √† quoi ressemble l‚Äôinflation : toutes les particules et forces que nous connaissons aujourd‚Äôhui √©taient absentes. Comme elle est principalement d√©crite par la RG, ses descriptions ne peuvent pas se passer de math√©matiques. Le r√¥le de nombreux chercheurs est de proposer un mod√®le math√©matique pour l‚Äôinflation et de calculer ce qu‚Äôil donne √† des moments ult√©rieurs, √† l‚Äô√©poque du plasma et m√™me jusqu‚Äô√† aujourd‚Äôhui. Enfin, vous comparez votre pr√©diction avec le signal mesur√© : vous notez les mod√®les, et vous gardez le meilleur (le plus proche des mesures) : c‚Äôest ce que fait la science moderne.
Les empreintes de l‚Äôinflation sur le signal micro-onde sont subtiles mais en disent long sur les propri√©t√©s de ‚Äòce qui‚Äô √©tait pr√©sent pendant l‚Äôinflation. Nous savons maintenant que l‚Äôinflation a principalement vu un type d‚Äô√©nergie sombre ‚Äì appel√© inflaton ‚Äì dominer, un type de pression n√©gative. Encore une fois, un tel fluide d√©clenche l‚Äôexpansion, ici la plus rapide de l‚Äôhistoire de l‚Äôunivers : taille multipli√©e par 1 [ins√©rez 138 z√©ros], en environ 0. [ins√©rez au moins 32 z√©ros] 1 seconde. De m√™me que l‚Äôexpansion de l‚Äôunivers d‚Äôaujourd‚Äôhui, c‚Äôest comme √™tre sur une feuille 2D d‚Äôespace-temps : c‚Äôest comme si un √™tre de dimension sup√©rieure √©tirait la feuille tout autour de vous. title: Mon doctorat en 12 esquisses.
text:
√ätre ou ne pas √™tre quantique





La mati√®re et les autres fluides du pr√©sent et du pass√©, et donc les particules dont ils sont constitu√©s, doivent avoir eu une histoire l√©g√®rement diff√©rente selon l‚Äôemplacement car l‚Äôobservation du ciel d‚Äôaujourd‚Äôhui le dit ; l‚Äôunivers n‚Äôest pas homog√®ne lorsque vous zoomez suffisamment, par exemple, il y a un nombre diff√©rent de galaxies selon les emplacements. L‚Äôorigine (dans le temps) de cette inhomog√©n√©it√© est suppos√©e √™tre la physique quantique pendant l‚Äôinflation. En remontant dans le temps, l‚Äôunivers pourrait atteindre des √©chelles inf√©rieures √† ce que nous ne pouvons pas voir avec nos yeux et m√™me plus petites. Mais dans ce cas, les choses ne suivent plus ce que l‚Äôon appelle la physique classique.
La physique classique est la science pr√©d√©termin√©e de ce que nous voyons tous les jours ; connaissant suffisamment de d√©tails sur un syst√®me √† un moment donn√© (masse, position, vitesse‚Ä¶), vous pouvez pr√©dire l‚Äô√©volution du syst√®me dans le temps et ce que vous mesurerez. Parfois, il vous manque des informations sur le syst√®me, et vous devez supposer diff√©rents sc√©narios pour le d√©but et donc l‚Äô√©volution. Chaque sc√©nario a une probabilit√© ; ici par exemple une mesure impr√©cise ou incompl√®te de la position initiale et de la vitesse donne un manque de connaissance √©galement plus tard.

title: Mon doctorat en 12 esquisses.
text:
Se sentir quantique





La physique quantique d√©crit √©galement les particules avec des probabilit√©s de pr√©sence dans l‚Äôespace et le temps, mais cela n‚Äôest pas d√ª √† notre propre manque de connaissance, mais plut√¥t √† une incertitude intrins√®que de l‚Äôobjet qui appara√Æt lorsque l‚Äôon zoome. Un objet quantique peut √™tre dans plusieurs √©tats en m√™me temps, comme s‚Äôil n‚Äôavait pas encore choisi d‚Äô√©tat dans notre r√©alit√© jusqu‚Äô√† ce que vous le mesuriez, alors que dans la physique classique, les choses existent d√©j√† ind√©pendamment de vous mais vous ne savez peut-√™tre pas encore dans quel √©tat. La fa√ßon la plus simple de le repr√©senter est, encore une fois, de sugg√©rer qu‚Äôil y a quelque chose en jeu dans une dimension suppl√©mentaire. Nous introduisons g√©n√©ralement des fonctionnalit√©s suppl√©mentaires pour la probabilit√© dans l‚Äôespace et le temps ; permettant aux probabilit√©s d‚Äôavoir une dimension angulaire appel√©e ‚Äòphase‚Äô. Deux particules peuvent ainsi interagir comme des vagues, mais avec plus de complexit√©, par exemple, leur interf√©rence (somme) d√©pend beaucoup de leur angle et peut annuler la probabilit√© de l‚Äôautre ou la renforcer.
Pour une onde de probabilit√© quantique donn√©e, certaines √©quations et principes dictent quelles formes sont autoris√©es dans l‚Äôespace et le temps. Par exemple, une onde peut avoir une probabilit√© concentr√©e dans l‚Äôespace (2√®me esquisse) mais implique une probabilit√© super √©tendue pour toutes les vitesses autoris√©es (3√®me esquisse). L‚Äôinverse est √©galement autoris√©, mais les probabilit√©s de positions et de vitesses trop pr√©cis√©ment connues simultan√©ment sont impossibles : incertitude quantique en jeu.

title: Mon doctorat en 12 esquisses.
text:
Pas de vide total





Retour √† l‚Äôunivers minuscule mais en expansion, la physique quantique en jeu. Les physiciens pensent que, suffisamment loin dans le pass√©, l‚Äôunivers compos√© d‚Äôinflaton pourrait √™tre dans son niveau d‚Äô√©nergie le plus bas, appel√© vide. Cependant, le vide quantique ne signifie pas strictement ‚Äò0‚Äô de quoi que ce soit, contrairement √† la physique classique, car m√™me au niveau le plus bas, la physique quantique montre des fluctuations d‚Äô√©nergie dans ce vide.
Th√©oriquement, le vide quantique ne peut pas avoir strictement 0 √©nergie, sinon cela contredirait l‚Äôincertitude quantique. Si nous d√©finissons le vide comme l‚Äôabsence de toute particule mesur√©e ; des paires de particules non mesurables sont autoris√©es √† √©merger de rien et √† s‚Äôannihiler avant que vous ayez le temps de les mesurer. Ces particules sont appel√©es ‚Äòvirtuelles‚Äô, mais cela ne signifie pas qu‚Äôelles n‚Äôexistent pas ; elles peuvent √™tre mesur√©es indirectement en mesurant d‚Äôautres particules r√©elles interagissant avec elles. Dans tous les cas, nous savons avec certitude qu‚Äôil y a un processus √©nerg√©tique en jeu apportant des fluctuations √† l‚Äôunivers jeune, ce qui donnera aujourd‚Äôhui des fluctuations dans le ciel (par exemple, le nombre de galaxies).

title: Mon doctorat en 12 esquisses.
text:
Un sous-monde dans chaque monde





Le dernier √©l√©ment du puzzle concerne l‚Äô√©chelle. Comme je l‚Äôai expliqu√©, il existe des situations quotidiennes o√π il nous manque des informations et o√π nous devons envisager tous les r√©sultats possibles avec des probabilit√©s. Cette incertitude classique est due √† un manque d‚Äôinformations sur le syst√®me. Le pire type provient d‚Äôune √©chelle plus petite que l‚Äô√©chelle d‚Äô√©tude. Rechercher des math√©matiques ou des descriptions g√©n√©rales de ; la forme de la France, le cycle de l‚Äôherbe et des plantes, l‚Äô√©volution de votre poids ou des bitcoins ou d‚Äôune mol√©cule ; tout cela peut n√©cessiter de prendre en compte ce qui se passe √† des √©chelles plus petites ; Normandie, vers en tant que recycleurs organiques, bruit de mesure, tous les individus sur un march√©, collisions al√©atoires avec d‚Äôautres particules, etc. Certains d‚Äôentre eux peuvent √™tre mod√©lis√©s comme un bruit de fond al√©atoire avec des probabilit√©s d√©finies, cela s‚Äôappelle la mod√©lisation stochastique.
La plupart du temps, il existe une √©chelle √† laquelle vous pouvez arr√™ter de zoomer car elle a une influence n√©gligeable par rapport √† votre pr√©cision souhait√©e. Et si nous faisions cela juste avant de zoomer sur la physique quantique pour √©tudier l‚Äôinflation cosmique ?

title: Mon doctorat en 12 esquisses.
text:
‚ÄúRelativit√© G√©n√©rale non-Lin√©aire pour l‚Äôinflation stochastique‚Äù





Vous avez maintenant tout ce dont vous avez besoin pour comprendre ma th√®se de doctorat. title: Doctor who?
text:
Hi! I‚Äôm Yoann and I‚Äôm a PhD student in Early Universe Cosmology at the Department of Applied Mathematics and Theoretical Physics at the University of Cambridge.
On this website, you will be able to find out more about:

My personal path if you wonder or prospect.
Material/Information if you are one of my students.
My everyday Physics if you bother.
More Physics if you‚Äôre starting from scratches.
My own curiosities.








In front of DAMTP, Cambridge.








Presenting my work in Paris.



As a Norman born in Brittany and raised in a city with an undefined identity (is Nantes a Breton land? It is the millennium question), Yoann was perhaps fated for problems. His first encounter with space, and most importantly cosmology, was NOT while watching the stars, an apple falling from a tree, a rocket launching, or while reading A Brief History of Time. Yoann simply doesn‚Äôt remember, because he just likes to learn a lot and has limited storage space. You can identify him as a fraud French, self-proclaimed Viking, who doesn‚Äôt want to talk about croissants and Paris at the first occasion.
After realising that zookeeper was not his destiny, that heart surgeon would take too long to study, and that politics‚Ä¶ well, anyway, he decided to do something involving maths. (!Nerd alert!) Maths were comforting and felt right, until an existential overdose when he realised that maybe he liked it mainly as a tool to answer day-to-day questions. He had a great time doing Physics in a Grande √âcole in Paris, followed by a master‚Äôs in Cambridge. He started his academic research journey at the former, where he worked on reconstructing the quantum structure of crystals. In Cambridge, he started looking into theoretical physics, and eventually his own series of ?why? questions converged (or diverged?) towards asking ?how? about the whole thing (more commonly called the Universe).
In the past 3+ years, Yoann has studied the early, fast-expanding universe by extending Einstein‚Äôs equations of General Relativity to fluctuations generated by the quantum vacuum. In this process, he has also looked at the classicalisation of spacetime correlations and has produced and run cutting-edge simulations of the inflating universe (and still does). Pen, paper and supercomputer is a lovely routine of his.
After work, Yoann goes to sleep. But before that, cooking his meal is usually the highlight of the day, when not topped by learning guitar for the billionth time. As a standard STEM clich√©, Yoann is also into hiking and bouldering. Beyond that, what is there to say, beyond the fact that entropy is non-decreasing.

title: My Thesis in 12 sketches.
text:
Gravity is simple: objects with a mass attract each other. The closer together they are or greater their masses, the stronger the attraction. However, this is only an approximation of reality. There is also an effect on time: time doesn‚Äôt pass the same way for everyone. General Relativity (GR) is the theory which calculates those effects. Take the case of these three humans: a second for one of them (the mountain or satellite guy vs the ground one) might be slightly longer for an another.
The difference between their clocks is due to the difference between their speeds and the gravitational force they endure (both slowing down time perception). This is not a noticeable effect on our planet, too light. Increase the mass of the planet and the difference of the speeds, the effect will become bigger. Still, GPS would not have today‚Äôs accuracy if those effects were not accounted for.

title: My Thesis in 12 sketches.
text:
Gravity is simple: objects with a mass attract each other. The closer together they are or greater their masses, the stronger the attraction. However, this is only an approximation of reality. There is also an effect on time: time doesn‚Äôt pass the same way for everyone. General Relativity (GR) is the theory which calculates those effects. Take the case of these three humans: a second for one of them (the mountain or satellite guy vs the ground one) might be slightly longer for an another.
The difference between their clocks is due to the difference between their speeds and the gravitational force they endure (both slowing down time perception). This is not a noticeable effect on our planet, too light. Increase the mass of the planet and the difference of the speeds, the effect will become bigger. Still, GPS would not have today‚Äôs accuracy if those effects were not accounted for.

title: My Thesis in 12 sketches.
text:
Fast Lives





So, people can have different beating rate for their clocks: your GR speed is your speed through space plus your speed through time. This speed is how fast you feel time. All theories have to pre-suppose something they can‚Äôt prove: in GR the speed of light is assumed to be always the same wherever the measure is done and the total time+space speed of any object is equal to the speed of light.
GR‚Äôs Maths suggest that we live on a sheet of paper (but 4 dimensions in reality, not 2) that can be bent when there is a massive object on it. When you fall from space to a planet, it is the same as going along a slide that leads to the planet. When you look at the curve of the slide, you can see that the notion of space and time depends on where you are (but also when). A curved line is indeed longer than a straight one: that explains why different people experience different travel times in space and time. You or anything (planets, blackholes, gas etc, but also light) undergo the curve of spacetime and in return also bend it. Still here? Good.

title: My Thesis in 12 sketches.
text:
Stars but not celebrities





The Earth is one of the 8 planets orbiting around a star ‚Äì our sun. Each of them has additional movements: they rotate around a North-South axis and this axis also slightly oscillates. The orbits are all almost circles, towards the same direction (except Venus and Uranus), and all in the same plane. Since all planets used to be part of the same cloud of matter orbiting around the sun, their numerous common traits are not surprising!
Gravity is not specific to our system. Our planet(s) and star have nothing special either. The same setup could exist for the ~100 billion stars in our galaxy, the Milky Way. Astronomists calculated at least 1 planet per star on average: a lot of possibilities for space colonies. However, it would take 100 000 years for us to travel across even in the best case (at light speed!), to which you add detours around the supermassive blackhole in the middle of our galaxy: Sagittarius A*. Supermassive black holes are also typical features of galaxies, at their center where matter collapses.

title: My Thesis in 12 sketches.
text:
Moses in a cosmic sea?





Let‚Äôs keep zooming out, we haven‚Äôt reached the scale of Cosmology yet, but we‚Äôre about to. The Milky Way belongs to a supercluster of galaxies called ‚ÄòVirgo‚Äô; a million times bigger. Some movements of those galaxies have been measured from Earth. In 1929, Edwin Hubble measured that some galaxies are moving away from us and the supercluster, the further, the fastest. It seems that distances everywhere become bigger: this is a proof that the universe is expanding.
However, within a certain distance to us, galaxies stick with us and the cluster and might even get closer. We will see that it comes from the competition between two forces: gravity and expansion, both described with GR. If the expansion continues, it is difficult to predict exactly how many galaxies will stay within Virgo; it probably will be separated into a hundred subclusters of galaxies, which could cluster more until merging into super galaxies.

title: My Thesis in 12 sketches.
text:
Cosmic Web





The biggest scale we can probe from observations is called the ‚Äòcosmic web‚Äô, 10 million of Virgo-like superclusters. Their distribution in space has a clear web pattern: superclusters have clustered with others thanks to gravity, but also empty bubbles have formed thanks to the expansion of the universe.
How is this possible? It feels like there is something growing or pushing things away that we can‚Äôt see. But we can see it and it‚Äôs everywhere: matter, light, anything with an energy dilates space and this is something we learn by writing the GR equation for the universe. However, there is also something accelerating that expansion, which is why we think that expansion won‚Äôt stop and reverse. None of the usual types of matter, light or forces allow that: can you imagine something with a negative pressure? something else is out there but nobody knows what it is and that‚Äôs why it is now called dark energy. We only know some of its properties and its quantity in the universe (~70%!).

title: My Thesis in 12 sketches.
text:
A backward history of time





One of the simplest ways to represent expansion is by using an (inaccurate) inflating balloon. It shows what you see from the center of the balloon, you (galaxy) and your surrounding friends (galaxies). Some of your friends are far enough to stand on the surface of the balloon: that‚Äôs the expansion. Some of them know each other and hold their hands or hug: that‚Äôs gravity. You can imagine that expansion hampered some of them to grab the hands of others or yours, or even broke some handshakes.
So, if the universe is currently a big, inflated balloon; what happens when going back in time? Do you get to hug all your friends? Can points hug? Well, that‚Äôs basically the origin of times and it‚Äôs complicated. What is even the right way to go back in time? This is researcher‚Äôs work to find out and it all depends on the content of the universe in time. For now, we discovered that all types of usual matter, light and force disappear into a hot plasma before we reach the point-like balloon. People thought the Big-Bang was there: let me explain you why it‚Äôs not.

title: My Thesis in 12 sketches.
section: The failure of the old Big-Bang against expansion in 18 holes
text:
The failure of the old Big-Bang against expansion in 18 holes





We measure distances by measuring the travel of light, the fastest speed allowed. But how fast is the expansion? I mentioned earlier that the further away an object is from us, the faster it recedes: is there a distance after which it could be faster than light? No.¬†Expansion doesn‚Äôt change the velocity of galaxies but rather makes the journey longer between them. That still means that light sent from us or some far neighbour might have to compete with an increasing distance, and sometimes expansion wins. Can you imagine playing golf on an expanding green‚Ä¶ Sometimes communication (i.e., light reaching from one area to another) is impossible between two regions of the universe. That‚Äôs the reason why even with powerful tools we can‚Äôt see the whole universe.
We still manage to receive microwave signals from the Big-Bang plasma, still travelling today, coming from all directions. The analysis of this signal suggested that places that were too far away from each other to have ever been in contact at that time, had actually interacted (for instance with the same light). From that discovery in the 60s, people decided we needed a pre-Big-Bang (or an extension) to allow a ‚Äòcontact‚Äô time and called it inflation.

title: My Thesis in 12 sketches.
text:
Hands-on Inflation





There isn‚Äôt really a shared way to imagine what inflation is like: all particles and forces we‚Äôre aware of today aren‚Äôt there. As it is mainly described by GR, its descriptions can‚Äôt go without mathematics. The role of many researchers is to propose a mathematical model for inflation and calculate what it gives at later times, at the plasma time and even until today. Finally, you compare your prediction with the measured signal: you score models, and you keep the best (the closest to measurements): that‚Äôs what modern science is.
The imprints of inflation on the microwave signal are subtle but tell a lot about the properties of ‚Äòwhat‚Äô was there during inflation. We now know that Inflation mainly saw a type of dark energy ‚Äì called inflaton- dominating, a type of negative pressure. Again, such a fluid triggers expansion, here the fastest in the universe‚Äôs history: size multiplied by 1[insert 138 zeros], in approximately 0.[insert at least 32 zeros]1 seconds. Similarly, to today‚Äôs universe expansion, it is like being on a 2D sheet of spacetime: it feels like some higher dimensional being was stretching the sheet everywhere around you. The main difference with today‚Äôs expansion is that the universe was small and so subjected to quantum effects.

title: My Thesis in 12 sketches.
section: To be or not to be quantum
text:
To be or not to be quantum





Matter and other fluids of the present and the past, and so particles they‚Äôre made of, must have had a slightly different history depending on the location because today‚Äôs sky observation says so; the universe is not homogeneous when you zoom enough, e.g., there are different number of galaxies for different locations. The origin (in time) of that inhomogeneity is thought to be quantum physics during Inflation. Backward in time, the universe might reach scales below what we cannot see with our eyeballs and even smaller. But in that case, things no longer follow what is called classical physics.
Classical physics is the pre-determined science of what we see everyday; knowing enough details about a system at a given time (mass, position, velocity‚Ä¶), you can predict the evolution of the system in time and what you will measure. Sometimes, you are missing information about the system, and you must assume different scenarios for the start and so the evolution. Each scenario has a probability; here for instance an unprecise or incomplete measure of the initial position and velocity gives a lack of knowledge also later.

title: My Thesis in 12 sketches.
text:
Feeling quantum





The easiest way to represent it is, again, by suggesting that there is something at play in an extra-dimension. We usually introduce extra features for the probability in space and time; allowing probabilities to have an angular dimension called ‚Äòphase‚Äô. Two particles‚Äô can thus interact like waves, but with more complexity, e.g., their interference (sum) depends a lot on their angle and can annihilate each other‚Äôs probability or strengthen it.
For a given quantum probability wave, some equations and principles dictate which shapes are allowed in space and time. For instance, a wave can have a concentrated probability in space (2nd sketch) but implies a super spread probability for all allowed velocities (3rd sketch). The opposite is also allowed, but both positions and velocity probabilities too precisely simultaneously known is impossible: quantum uncertainty at play.

title: My Thesis in 12 sketches.
text:
No such thing as empty





Back to the tiny but inflating universe, quantum physics at play. Physicists think that, far enough in the past, the universe made of inflaton could be in its lowest energy level, called vacuum. However, quantum vacuum doesn‚Äôt strictly mean ‚Äò0‚Äô of anything, as opposed to classical physics, because even at the lowest level quantum physics show energy fluctuations in that vacuum.
Theoretically, quantum vacuum cannot have a strict 0 energy, otherwise it would contradict the quantum uncertainty. If we define vacuum as the absence of any measured particle; unmeasurable particles pairs are allowed to emerge from nothing and annihilate before you have time to measure them. Those particles are called ‚Äòvirtual‚Äô, but it doesn‚Äôt mean they don‚Äôt exist; they can be measured indirectly by measuring other real particles interacting with them. In all cases, we know for sure that there is some energetic process down there bringing fluctuations to the young universe, which will today give fluctuations in the sky (e.g.¬†number of galaxies).

title: My Thesis in 12 sketches.
section: Mind the gap between the world and the sub-world
text:
Mind the gap between the world and the sub-world





The last piece of the puzzle is about scaling. As I explained, there are everyday situations where we miss information and must consider all possible outcomes with probabilities. That classical uncertainty is due to a lack of information about the system. The worst type comes from a scale smaller than the scale of study. Searching for mathematics or general descriptions of; the shape of France, the grass and plants cycle, the evolution of your weight or bitcoins or of a molecule; all of those might require the consideration of what is happening at smaller scales; Normandie, worms as organic recyclers, measure noise, all individuals in a market, random collisions with other particles etc. Some of them can be modeled as random background noise with defined probabilities, it‚Äôs called stochastic modeling.
Most of times, there is a scale at which you can stop zooming because it has a negligible influence compared to your desired precision. What if we were doing that just before zooming into Quantum Physics to study cosmic inflation?

title: My Thesis in 12 sketches.
text:
‚ÄúNon-linear general relativity for stochastic inflation‚Äù





You now have everything you need to understand my PhD. Because General Relativity and Quantum Physics are not compatible but exchanging phenomena, I want to study the propagation in time of the initial quantum fluctuations of inflation by treating it as a stochastic noise when it becomes classical and so compatible with General Relativity. If this works, that will allow me to predict the distribution of today‚Äôs types of matter in the universe, for instance the patterns of clusters and galaxies, but also to validate or rule out certain types of starts for the universe.
If it is still blurry, contact me for questions or meditate with those chatGPT-generated illustrations of my thesis‚Äô keywords! Thanks for reading.

title: Research
section: Non-Linear General Relativity for Stochastic Inflation (Early Universe Cosmology)
text:
Non-Linear General Relativity for Stochastic Inflation (Early Universe Cosmology)
PhD, 2022-2026, DAMTP, University of Cambridge.

Abstract for professionals

My PhD project will advance the early universe theory of inflation, which explains the origin of galaxies and large-scale structure in the Universe, by developing stochastic methods with nonlinear evolution to make quantitative statistical predictions from inflationary models. Non-Gaussian signatures are inherently present in primordial fluctuations due to the non-linearities produced by both general relativity and the fact that the inflaton potential responsible for driving inflation may be interacting.
The goal of this project is to analytically and numerically model nonlinear inflationary dynamics in order to make bispectrum and higher-order correlator predictions which encompass a much broader range of inflationary scenarios, including those with multiple fields. This is an important discriminant between competing inflation models that can be used to distinguish them observationally.
An important element of the project will be to exploit the new GRChombo numerical relativity pipeline to model these nonlinear effects using full 3D general relativistic simulations, comparing the results with perturbative analytic expectations from effective field theory. In the last years, consequent insights have been made by the DAMTP cosmology group lead by Dr.¬†Paul Shellard, now able to constrain a wide range of these models by using innovative separable techniques to extract and reconstruct the bispectrum (three-point correlator) from Planck satellite maps of the cosmic microwave background (CMB). Direct confrontation with new observational data sets, from both CMB experiments (Simons Observatory) and galaxy surveys (SDSS, DES etc), will guide and constrain the understanding of inflation in fundamental physics. Stochastic nonlinear methods have other wide-ranging applications, including the creation of primordial black holes and the generation of gravitational waves in the early universe.



Abstract for newcomers

I work on the cosmology of the early universe. This means finding the best mathematical description of the first few seconds of the universe, considering it as a dynamic system, and testing the predictions of this model against real astrophysical data. In particular, I will predict the distribution in space of the different types of energy and matter at any time using a promising theory called Stochastic Inflation. Inflationrefers to the first instants of the universe which allowed an exponential growth of its size ‚Äì and since then, the universe kept expanding. Stochastic refers to the mathematical description of the early universe‚Äôs quantum fluctuations; random fluctuations of energy in the initial vacuum propagated in time and produced an inhomogeneous universe; e.g.¬†today super cluster of galaxies against empty millions of light years.
There is a time at which those perturbations are big enough to be accounted for with the rival theory of quantum physics: the General Relativity of Albert Einstein, which describes gravity between massive objects (e.g.; solar system; you and the Earth). We can make predictions about the future of these growing quantum perturbations from an Inflation model by using a numerical simulation of gravity. By doing so, I hope to support the growing link between these two theories (Quantum Physics and General Relativity). This requires ambitious simulation software, and so I am a member of the GRChombo collaboration which develops such code.

title: Research
section: Slow-roll oscillating non-Gaussianities from singular kinetic pre-inflationary universe (Early Universe Cosmology)
text:
Slow-roll oscillating non-Gaussianities from singular kinetic pre-inflationary universe (Early Universe Cosmology)
Master Thesis, 2021-2022, Cavendish Laboratory, University of Cambridge.

Abstract for professionals

Modern inflation theory is based on Mukhanov-Sasaki equations which give a perturbative framework to propagate initial quantum fluctuations as sources of the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) anisotropies encountered at the recombination epoch. Following previous work on initial conditions for the power spectrum, this work extends the kinetic pre-inflation model to the derivation of the primordial bispectrum, related to 3-point correlations. We derive here the main perturbations contributing to the bispectrum thanks to the In-In formalism for different initial conditions of a simple constant slow-roll and single-field inflation. In addition to an oscillating locally-shaped bispectrum, it is found that the dependence on the time and nature of the transition between pre-inflation and inflation is strong. As a main result, UV and IR divergences are encountered for the non-Gaussianities, showed to be independent of the choice of the vacuum and so treated within the assumption of an old transition time compared to the experimental cutoff.



Abstract for newcomers

This work studied a particular model of initial conditions for the universe, i.e.¬†of a type of inflationary universe. While most models don‚Äôt incorporate any origin and focus on the inflation process itself, this model combine both aspects by providing an initial singularity at the start and then propagates the subsequent universe into a ‚Äúkinetic‚Äù era before transitioning to the usual models with a stable inflation of the apparent size of the universe.
As this is quite a peculiar formulation, usual mathematical tools to compute post-inflation observable quantities need some careful study. This is what we did to compute the correlation between each 3 points of the sky at the time of the Hot Big-Bang following Inflation.

title: Research
section: Optimal combination of the spatial correlation function and galaxy cluster counts (Cosmology)
text:
Optimal combination of the spatial correlation function and galaxy cluster counts (Cosmology)
Undergraduate Summer Internship, CEA, Paris-Saclay.

Abstract

To understand the story of the universe, physicists have identified cosmological observables : the CMB, supernovae but also galaxy clusters hosting most of the matter in the universe. From these last ones, many direct and indirect observables can be reconstructed including galaxy clusters counts and space correlations. Between these two, correlations are expected and encourage the exploration of a unification of two distinct formalisms - at least in the refinement of cosmological parameters.

title: Research
section: N-Representable one-electron reduced density matrices reconstruction at non-zero temperatures (Quantum Cristallography)
text:
N-Representable one-electron reduced density matrices reconstruction at non-zero temperatures (Quantum Cristallography)
Bachelor Thesis, 2019-2021, CentraleSup√©lec/CNRS, Paris-Saclay University.

Abstract

This article retraces different methods that have been explored to account for the atomic thermal motion in the reconstruction of one-electron reduced density matrices from experimental X-ray structure factors (XSF) and directional Compton profiles (DCP). Attention has been paid to propose the simplest possible model, which obeys the necessary N-representability conditions, while accurately reproducing all available experimental data. The deconvolution of thermal effects makes it possible to obtain an experimental static density matrix, which can directly be compared with theoretical 1-RDM (reduced density matrix). It is found that above a 1% statistical noise level, the role played by Compton scattering data becomes negligible and no accurate 1-RDM is reachable. Since no thermal 1-RDM is available as a reference, the quality of an experimentally derived temperature-dependent matrix is difficult to assess. However, the accuracy of the obtained static 1-RDM, through the performance of the refined observables, is strong evidence that the Semi-Definite Programming method is robust and well adapted to the reconstruction of an experimental dynamical 1-RDM.

section: Nash equilibirum in network games (Game Theory)
text:
Nash equilibirum in network games (Game Theory)
Undergraduate project, 2018-2019, Clemenceau Preparatory Classes.

Abstract

In this work, I studied games called ‚ÄòShapley Network Design‚Äô which model the passage from A to B with a fixed number of paths and travellers. I derived the general Nash equilibrium for quadratic costs and compared it to the optimal equilibrium obtained thanks to a genetic algorithm.
